title: The Ratings Game: Netflix’s stock now a ‘top pick’ at J.P. Morgan
first_para:
The stock

                                         which was little changed in afternoon trade Tuesday, has gained 4.1% since it reported after the Jan. 17 close fourth-quarter earnings that beat earnings and subscriber expectations, while the S&P 500 index

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, +0.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has climbed 8.8%. Meanwhile, stocks within Anmuth’s internet coverage have advanced more than 8% on average over the same period.

GOOG, +0.31%

title: How to ‘Marie Kondo’ your subscriptions with the click of a button
first_para:
On Monday, Apple 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.07%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         announced a new streaming video service that will allow users to subscribe to channels such as HBO 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    T, +0.85%

                                         providing their own subscription video services, some have speculated that consumers have reached “peak subscription,” while others have complained about the amount of money they are shelling out each month to keep up with the latest shows.

title: Apple targets payments, news, TV and videogames in event aimed at subscription services
first_para:
Apple’s efforts with video programming are twofold: The company intends to make it easier for users to purchase subscriptions to services like HBO and Showtime through its new Apple TV offering, and the smartphone maker will also provide original content with big-name stars on a Netflix-like 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         streaming service called Apple TV+.

title: Everything coming to Netflix in April — and what’s leaving
first_para:
The streaming platform 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                          has some very dark shows and movies planned for spring. The second season of “Chilling Adventures of Sabrina,” chronicling Sabrina Spellman’s witch adventures, and Netflix original “Suzanna: Buried Alive,” about a pregnant woman who is murdered and whose spirit seeks revenge on her killers, will hit Netflix early next month. “Black Summer,” about the early days of a zombie apocalypse, arrives April 11. “The Silence,” featuring “Sabrina” stars Kiernan Shipka and Miranda Otto, about a world under attack by creatures who hunt human prey using sound, hits the streaming platform on April 12.

title: The Technical Indicator: Charting a bullish second-quarter start, S&P 500 nails major resistance (2,873)

title: Justice Department reportedly warns Academy against blocking Netflix at the Oscars
first_para:
The Justice Department has warned the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences not to limit the eligibility of streaming services for Oscars, Variety reported, citing a letter from Makan Delrahim, the chief of the DOJ's antitrust division. The report quoted Delrahim as writing that if the Academy "establishes certain eligibility requirements for the Oscars that eliminate competition without procompetitive justification, such conduct may raise antitrust concerns." Steven Spielberg has reportedly wanted to restrict movies that debut on Netflix 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         at the same time they appear in movie theaters.

title: Netflix's stock rallies, erasing previous losses after Apple announces rival streaming
first_para:
Shares of Netflix Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied 1.3% toward fresh intraday highs in afternoon trade Monday, reversing earlier losses, after Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         announced its rival new Apple TV+ service. The new service will include original programming, and offer suggestions for shows and movies from over 150 streaming apps, including Amazon.com Inc.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Amazon Prime and Hulu, but not Netflix. Reed Hastings, Netflix's CEO, said last week that the company had chosen not to integrate into Apple's services, while the Netflix app will continue to be available in Apple's app store. Netflix's stock was down as much as 1.0% as Apple started announcing its new services. Over teh past 12 months, Netflix shares have rallied 21.4% and Apple's stock has climbed 13.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, +0.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 8.4%.

title: Amazon's stock surges above 200-day moving average
first_para:
Shares of Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied 1.9% in afternoon trade Monday, which puts them on track to send a bullish technical signal by closing above the widely followed 200-day moving average (DMA). A close above the 200-DMA, which many chart watchers view as a dividing line between longer-term uptrends and downtrends, would be the third time it has done so over the past 3 1/2 months. The two previous closes above the line, on Jan. 31 and Dec. 3, were followed by quick reversals back below the line the next day. The 200-DMA currently extends to $1,730.20, according to FactSet. The last time it closed above the line for at least 2-straight days was on Nov. 9. Of the other FAANG stocks, shares of Netflix Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         have closed above its 200-DMA since Jan. 30 and Google-parent Alphabet Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GOOGL, +0.36%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has closed above it since March 1, while Facebook Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FB, +0.21%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.09%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         are below their respective 200-DMAs. Microsoft's stock has climbed 12.5% over the past three months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, +0.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has tacked on 9.3%. In a note to clients Monday, Wells Fargo said Amazon is still gaining retail customers, and they're visiting more frequently, with the company's "share of wallett" in the fourth quarter increasing 33% from a year ago.

title: Disney stock upgraded at BMO ahead of investor day
first_para:
BMO Capital Markets analyst Daniel Salmon became the latest to upgrade shares of Walt Disney Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DIS, -0.33%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         raising his rating on the stock to outperform from market perform on Wednesday. He sees positive catalysts in the company's forthcoming launch of its Disney+ streaming service, the opening of two new Star Wars lands in theme parks, and the possibility for buybacks in the next year. "We continue to like Netflix 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and Amazon 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         more than Disney, but are comfortable recommending all three, as we expect them all to be long-term winners in global [direct-to-consumer] streaming," Salmon wrote. When Disney holds its investor day on Thursday, Salmon expects the company to "end the debate on how low near-term EPS goes" and offer subscriber-based indicators for the direct-to-consumer platforms, as well as a price for Disney+. Salmon's upgrade follows one from Cowen & Co. on Tuesday. The stock is up 0.7% in premarket trading Wednesday, and it's gained 6.6% so far this year. The S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, +0.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has risen 15% in that time.

title: Apple streaming service won't offer Netflix subscription, Hastings says
first_para:
Netflix Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         will not be part of Apple Inc.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.09%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         new streaming service, Chief Executive Reed Hastings said late Monday, Variety reported. Speaking at a press event in Los Angeles, Hastings confirmed what many had already suspected. "Apple is a great company," he said, according to Variety. "We have chosen not to integrate into their services." Netflix is currently available through Apple's app store, and that is not expected to change. Apple is expected to unveil its highly anticipated streaming service next week. While it will feature some original shows, it is expected to also bolster its offerings by selling subscriptions to some third-party streaming services, such as HBO and Showtime, much as Amazon.com Inc.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Prime service does. Speaking on other subjects, Hastings said Netflix won't be entering the potentially lucrative Chinese market for a while. "We will be blocked in China for a long time," he said

title: Apple should consider a big M&A deal to catch up on rivals in streaming: Wedbush analyst
first_para:
Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.09%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         should consider doing a big, strategic merger or acquisition to help it catch up on rivals including Netflix Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.52%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         in creating content for its coming video streaming service, Wedbush said Tuesday. "While acquisitions have not been in Apple's core DNA, the clock has struck midnight for Cupertino in our opinion and building content organically is a slow and arduous path, which highlights the clear need for Apple to do larger, strategic M&A (a24, Lionsgate, Sony Pictures, CBS/Viacom, Netflix, MGM) around content over the coming year to "double down" and drive the services flywheel especially with its new video subscription service set to be rolled out," analyst Daniel Ives said in a note to clients. Apple has announced a March 25 event at the Steve Jobs Theater in Cupertino, its headquarters, to announce details of the streaming service, which is not expected to launch until the fall. Ives is hoping the company is planning to use the service to further expand its entire services offering into areas such as video content and even gaming in the next decade. Services remains "the wild card in driving the valuation higher for Apple," he said, estimating that part of its business is wroth about $400 billion on a standalone basis. The streaming segment could be worth more than $50 billion in revenue by fiscal 2020, doubling from fiscal 2016 levels, he wrote. Apple is spending about $1 billion on content this year, but is still playing from behind in the content race with Netflix, Amazon, Disney 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DIS, -0.34%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and AT&T/Time Warner 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    T, +0.82%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         he said. Apple shares were slightly higher premarket, but are down 1.6% in the last 12 months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, +0.16%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 1.9% and the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, +0.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         is flat.

title: In One Chart: Why everybody’s face is still buried in their phones, in one eye-opening chart

The numbers on their own are pretty stark — every minute around the world, 188 million emails are sent, 3.8 million Google

title: The Ratings Game: Tesla is like Apple and Salesforce, but don’t buy the stock right now, analyst says
first_para:
“Tesla is fundamentally changing not only the way cars are built but also how they are bought and sold. To us, this is similar to what Apple did with the advent of the iPhone, Amazon

                                         did with video, and Salesforce did with software.”

title: Will consumers finally decide they’re drowning in streaming services?
first_para:
The Milwaukee, Wisc.-area married father of two was soaking in subscriptions for years. But then he did the math, smarting from a one-two punch in higher rates from Hulu and Netflix

title: Deep Dive: Stocks took a big hit Friday, and these shares fell the most
first_para: Only one day after crystal-clear dovish signals by the Federal Reserve helped push stocks higher, fear of a recession sent bond prices soaring and stock prices tumbling.

title: MarketWatch First Take: Apple leaves a lot of questions about its subscription services unanswered
first_para:
These efforts are either re-dos of prior efforts by Apple — such as News+ (hello again, Apple Newstand?) — or forays into extremely competitive markets, such as original video content, videogame streaming and fee-less credit cards. If anyone needs a reminder of how competitive and costly some of these arenas can be, just take a look at Netflix Inc.’s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.50%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         negative cash flow and its high content costs, and the host of growing entrants into videogame streaming, including news last week from Alphabet Inc.’s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GOOG, +0.37%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Google and its Stadia service.

title: Facebook, Amazon, other internet giants are weathering Washington’s body blows
first_para:
1. Criminal investigation: . The DOJ and the U.S. Attorney’s office for the Eastern District of New York are reportedly looking into the data-sharing deals Facebook struck with tech companies, including smartphone companies, according to a March 13 New York Times article. Among Facebook’s data-sharing arrangements, per a December 18, 2018 New York Times article: : Microsoft’s Bing search engine was allowed to see the names of almost all Facebook users’ friends without consent; Netflix

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.35%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                          and Spotify were able to read Facebook users’ private messages; Amazon.com

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, +0.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                          could obtain users’ names and contact information through their friends; and Yahoo could see streams of friends’ posts.

                                         of gaming. Gamers will be able to stream complex games to their screens without needing consoles or high-powered graphic chips in their computers.

title: Hey Kim Kardashian — there’s nothing ‘really funny’ about shoplifting
first_para:
The problem is, there’s a collective idea that shoplifting isn’t a big deal. In fact, it’s even a plotline in the second season of “The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina” streaming on Netflix

title: The genius $10 item professional organizers say they can’t live without
first_para:
What’s more, we’re clearly sick of it, at least if the social media hype about Netflix’s

And while organizational items can go for a pretty penny — Marie Kondo’s set of boxes is $89 — pros say you can spend a fraction of that and still declutter.

title: You don’t need a 4-year college degree for these high-paying jobs at Google, Apple, Netflix
first_para:
One UX designer for Netflix 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.45%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         , Hannah Maddy, spoke to LinkedIn about her lack of a four-year degree. “Not only do I not have a four-year degree, but I’m also a high school dropout and worked the graveyard shift as a baker until I landed my first design gig,” Maddy told LinkedIn. She got the skills to land her Netflix job by working on side projects with friends, learning to code online and diligently sending out her portfolio to employers, she told the site.

title: Apple leaves a lot of questions about its subscription services unanswered
first_para:
These efforts are either re-dos of prior efforts by Apple — such as News+ (hello again, Apple Newstand?) — or forays into extremely competitive markets, such as original video content, videogame streaming and fee-less credit cards. If anyone needs a reminder of how competitive and costly some of these arenas can be, just take a look at Netflix Inc.’s

                                    GOOG, +0.37%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Google and its Stadia service.

first_para:
“Netflix

                                         has an inferior competitive position to Apple over time, as we see it, in both: a) customer acquisition costs; and b) content costs,” wrote Martin, who has a strong buy rating and $225 price target on the stock. “Apple has zero consumer acquisition costs since it will first target its captive 900 million global unique users, which are the wealthiest consumers in the world.”

title: Market Snapshot: U.S. stock futures indicate fresh losses ahead for Wall Street
first_para: U.S. stocks closed mostly lower Monday after data showing weakness on the global economic front triggered heavy losses at the end of last week while investors continued to fret over the inversion of the yield curve. However, the Dow bucked the trend to rise as shares of Boeing Co. rallied after recent losses.

title: Tesla bears are now making crazy claims, short-circuiting their cause
first_para:
I’ve followed Tilson’s work for over 10 years, and I have a lot of respect for him. He’s a sharp thinker and a good writer. His take-down of Netflix 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, +0.52%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         several years ago was an epic piece of investment research. It, too, turned out to be wrong. But that didn’t detract from the thoroughness of the work. And to Tilson’s credit, he recognized this in time and went long Netflix for a decent profit.
